file = {Wiin-Nielsen_1962_ON TRANSFORMATION OF KINETIC ENERGY BETWEEN THE VERTICAL SHEAR FLOW AND THE.pdf:C\:\\Dropbox\\Zotero\\storage\\LNZJKF85\\Wiin-Nielsen_1962_ON TRANSFORMATION OF KINETIC ENERGY BETWEEN THE VERTICAL SHEAR FLOW AND THE.pdf:application/pdf}

abstract = {Some estimates of truncation errors due to vertical finite differences are given. The truncation errors amount to at most 10 \% in the phase-speed of the basic mode in a model atmosphere in which the vertical shear of the basic
column2: zonal flow vanishes. An increase of the vertical resolution results in rapidly decreasing truncation errors in this case.In a model atmosphere
column3: in which the vertical windshear is different from zero
column4: and the static stability parameter is a function of pressure
column5: we find small truncation errors in the initial displacement of the wave
column6: but large errors in the initial amplification.The initial development of a baroclinic wave is evaluated in three different baroclinic models. The models differ only in the vertical variation of the static stability parameter which is a simple function of pressure in the first model
column7: a constant in the next and zero in the third model. It is shown that the vertical variation of static stability is important for the amplification and the slope of the wave in the vertical direction.The initial change of the kinetic energy in the models is computed as a function of wave-length. It is shown that the change of kinetic energy is larger in the models where the static stability parameter is constant or zero than in the models where it varies with pressure.The last section contains some comments on the upper boundary condition. It is shown that the conditions ? and ? μ ?(? = geopotential) at the upper boundary are equivalent in certain problems.}

file = {Lally_1962_Meteorological Measurements—The Gentle Rain or the Deluge.pdf:C\:\\Dropbox\\Zotero\\storage\\I2VWDFJX\\Lally_1962_Meteorological Measurements—The Gentle Rain or the Deluge.pdf:application/pdf}
journal = {Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society}
abstract = {A model of a cumulo-nimbus updraught is presented
column5: entraining environmental air according to the simple law that the inflow velocity at any height is proportional to the upward velocity of the plume. With this model
column6: the shape of the cloud as well as its other properties follow from the dynamics
column7: and cloud development is size-dependent. The virtual temperature excess at cloud base is taken as zero; this seems the only appropriate assumption for a steadystate plume model. The thermodynamical treatment is made with few approximations
column8: and the effect of freezing on the dynamics is included in a simple fashion. Some preliminary calculations result in realistic cloud shapes and reasonable values for the internal properties.}

@article{newkirk_daytime_1962: file = {Squires_Turner_1962_An entraining jet model for cumulo-nimbus updraughts.pdf:C\:\\Dropbox\\Zotero\\storage\\PVZXW2LQ\\Squires_Turner_1962_An entraining jet model for cumulo-nimbus updraughts.pdf:application/pdf}
title = {An entraining jet model for cumulo-nimbus updraughts}

abstract = {The problem of satellite observation of infrared radiation is studied in terms of geometric and spectral variation of atmospheric radiation. As an aid in interpretation of satellite observations
column2: the anisotropy of out-going radiation at the top of the atmosphere and at the satellite level is computed for different atmospheric models and spectral regions to characterize radiation from the lower
column4: and high troposphere. It is shown that limb darkening is an extremely sharp property of the atmosphere as viewed from an orbiting satellite.}

@article{newkirk_daytime_1962: title = {The use of satellite observations for atmospheric radiation studies}

abstract = {Observations of the diurnal (S1) and semidiurnal (S2) wind oscillations between 80 and 100 km show that their amplitudes are of the same magnitude as the mean winds. Both periods show pronounced seasonal changes in the same sense as
column2: but much larger than would be expected from surface data forS2
column3: and in agreement with the idea of a thermal cause forS1. From the observed wind oscillations the pressure oscillations can be computed. The pressure amplitudes are about 5 percent or
column6: indicating a fifty to hundred-fold increase compared to the low atmosphere
column7: as suggested by theory. But the phase ofS2 does not show the expected reversal relative to the ground.S1 seems to be much more regular than at the earth's suface where it is greatly disturbed by local influences. The few data on the lunar semidiurnal (L2) oscillation show also the increse of the amplitudes with height.}

@article{newkirk_daytime_1962: title = {Wind and pressure oscillations in the upper atmosphere}
abstract = {It is shown that the main phase of great magnetic storms is composed of two parts
column2: most clearly characterized by their decay rate: one decays much more rapidly than the other. It is suggested that extraordinarily intense storms are largely due to an abnormal growth of the rapidly decaying part. Because of its rapid decay
column3: the combination with the slow decay part gives a rather sharp change of decay rate
column4: which is commonly seen for great storms. The results are discussed in the light of present theoretical knowledge.}

@article{newkirk_daytime_1962: file = {Akasofu et al_1963_The main phase of great magnetic storms.pdf:C\:\\Dropbox\\Zotero\\storage\\TJPS4XHT\\Akasofu et al_1963_The main phase of great magnetic storms.pdf:application/pdf}
title = {The main phase of great magnetic storms}
abstract = {It is shown that the growth of auroral electrojects can greatly enhance the equatorial electro jet. This indicates that a part of the return current
column2: spreading from the auroral zone to the ionosphere in low and middle latitudes
column3: can extend to as far as the late afternoon side along the magnetic equator. The current systems inferred so far for polar magnetic substorms may have to be revised to include such an intense return current. The enhancement is used to infer the distribution of the highly conductive region along the magnetic equator. It is shown that the conductivity is about 4–7 times higher there than in middle latitudes.}

@article{newkirk_daytime_1962: file = {Akasofu_Chapman_1963_The enhancement of the equatorial electrojet during polar magnetic substorms.pdf:C\:\\Dropbox\\Zotero\\storage\\7G4M367A\\Akasofu_Chapman_1963_The enhancement of the equatorial electrojet during polar magnetic substorms.pdf:application/pdf;Snapshot:C\:\\Dropbox\\Zotero\\storage\\LPGGJUGR\\JZ068i009p02375.html:text/html}
title = {The enhancement of the equatorial electrojet during polar magnetic substorms}
abstract = {The electrical charging which results from collisions between ice crystals and a simulated hailstone is measured as a function of their temperature difference
column2: and of the size and impact velocity of the crystals. It is found that the sign of the charging is governed by that of the temperature difference
column3: the hailstone becoming negatively charged if it is warmer than the rebounding crystals. The magnitude of the charging is proportional to the temperature difference but rather insensitive to the size and impact velocity of the crystals. With a temperature difference of 5 ⚬C
column4: a rebounding crystal of diameter about 50 μ produces
column6: a charge of 5 × 10-9 e.s.u. The electrification of an artificial pellet of soft hail growing by the accretion of supercooled water droplets (riming) is also investigated. Freezing of the droplets on the hailstone is accompanied by the ejection of positively charged ice splinters
column7: the hailstone acquiring a negative charge. The manner in which the rates of charging and splinter production vary with the air temperature
column8: drop diameter and impact velocity has been established. In a typical experiment
column10: droplets of diameter 80 μ impacting at 10 m s-1 freeze to produce
column12: 12 splinters and a charge of 4 × 10-6 e.s.u. per drop. Droplets of diameter less than 30 μ produce few splinters and little charging. The results of both sets of experiments are interpreted in terms of the authors' theory of charge separation in ice under the influence of a temperature gradient
column13: and are used to calculate probable rates of charge generation in thunderstorms. It appears that the electrification which accompanies the growth of pellets of soft hail through the freezing and splintering of supercooled droplets is capable of generating and separating charge at the required rate of about 1 C km-3 min-1 but
column14: while rebounding ice crystals will usually charge the hailstones in the same (negative) sense
column15: this mechanism will contribute only slightly to thunderstorm electrification.}
